page.title: Translations of One Thousand and One Nights

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Translations of ''One Thousand and One Nights''}} The translations of ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'' have been made into virtually every major language of the world.<ref>{{cite book | editors=[[Wen-chin Ouyang]], Geert Jan van Gelder | title =New Perspectives on Arabian Nights| publisher =Routledge | year =2014 | page =ix | isbn =1317983939}}</ref> They began with the French translation by [[Antoine Galland]] (titled ''[[Les mille et une nuits]]'', finished in 1717). Galland's translation was essentially an adapted Arabic manuscript of Syrian origins and oral tales recorded by him in [[Paris]] from a [[Maronite]] Arab from [[Aleppo]] named Youhenna Diab or Hanna Diab.<ref>{{harvnb|Zipes|2007|p=53}}</ref>
The first English translation appeared in 1706 and was made from Galland's version; being anonymous, it is known as the [[Grub Street]] edition. It exists in two known copies kept in the [[Bodleian Library]] and in the [[Princeton University Library]].<ref name="1001 nights">{{harvnb|Nishio|Yamanaka|2006|p=222}}</ref> Since then several English reissues appeared simultaneously in 1708. As early as the end of the 18th century the English translation based on Galland was brought to [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], [[Montreal]], [[Philadelphia]], [[New York City|New York]] and [[Sydney]].<ref name="1001 nights"/> Galland-based English translations were superseded by that made by [[Edward William Lane]] in 1839–41. In the 1880s an unexpurgated and complete English translation, ''[[The Book of the Thousand Nights and a Night]]'', was made by [[Richard Francis Burton]].
The original scattered Arabic texts were collected in four corpuses: the so-called [[Calcutta I]] or the Shirwanee Edition (1814–18, 2 volumes), [[Bulaq Edition|Bulaq]] or the Cairo Edition (1835, 2 volumes), [[Breslau Edition]] (1825–38, 8 volumes) and [[Calcutta II]] or the W.H. Macnaghten Edition (1839–42, 4 volumes). Some translations starting from Galland were [[censored]] due to lewd content.<ref>{{harvnb|Marzolph|2004|p=516}}</ref>
==French translations== ===Galland=== {{main|Les mille et une nuits}} Galland based his translation on a three- or four-volume manuscript from the 14th or 15th century.<ref name="Irwin 2004 16">{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=16}}</ref> Three volumes of that manuscript were placed in the [[National Library of France]].<ref name="Irwin 2004 16"/> Galland's translation altered the style, tone and content of the Arabic text. Designed to appeal, it omitted sophisticated or dark elements while enhancing exotic and magical elements and became the basis of most children's versions of ''One Thousand and One Nights''.<ref>{{cite book | last =Sallis | first =Eva | title =Sheherazade Through the Looking Glass: The Metamorphosis of the 'Thousand and One Nights'| publisher = Routledge| year =2013 |page=49| isbn =1136817522}}</ref>
===Mardrus=== In 1926–1932 a lavishly decorated 12-volume edition of [[J. C. Mardrus]]' translation, titled ''[[Le livre des mille nuits et une nuit]]'', appeared. Soviet and Russian scholar [[Isaak Filshtinsky]], however, considered Mardrus' translation inferior to others due to presence of chunks of text, which Mardrus conceived himself to satisfy the tastes of his time.<ref name="Salye">{{cite web | url =http://www.sheherazade.ru/about-translations-1001-night.htm| script-title=ru:О переводах '1001 ночи'|publisher= Sheherazade.ru|work=Тысяча и одна ночь. Избранные сказки|language=Russian|author=[[Isaak Filshtinsky]]| accessdate =17 Aug 2014}}</ref> According to [[Robert Irwin (writer)|Robert Irwin]], "Mardrus took elements which were there in the original Arabic and worked them up, exaggerating and inventing, reshaping the ''Nights'' in such a manner that the stories appear at times to have been written by [[Oscar Wilde]] or [[Stéphane Mallarmé]]".<ref>{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=37}}</ref> In response to criticism of his translation by academic Arabists, Mardrus promised to produce a tome of learned commentary and justificatory pieces which he, however, failed to do.<ref>{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=39}}</ref>
==English translations== Unlike the Grub Street version, [[Jonathan Scott (orientalist)|Jonathan Scott]] made the first [[literal translation]] of Galland. Titled ''The Arabian Nights Entertainments'', it appeared in 1811. Then Henry Torrens translated the first fifty nights from Calcutta II, which were published in 1838. Having heard that [[Edward William Lane]] began his own translation, Torrens abandoned his work.<ref name="Irwin 2004 23">{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=23}}</ref> Lane translated from the Bulaq corpus.<ref name="Irwin 2004 23"/> He declared that "Galland has excessively perverted the work".<ref name="Irwin 2004 24">{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=24}}</ref> According to Lane, Galland's "acquaintance with Arab manners and customs was insufficient to preserve him always from errors of the grossest description".<ref name="Irwin 2004 24"/> Working with the Bulaq corpus, Lane occasionally cross-checked against Calcutta I and Breslau corpus.<ref name="Irwin 2004 25">{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=25}}</ref> His translation, however, became incomplete.<ref name="Irwin 2004 25"/> In 1923 a translation by [[Edward Powys Mathers]] based on the French translation by [[J. C. Mardrus]] appeared.
Another translation attempt was made by [[John Payne (poet)|John Payne]] (''The Book of the Thousand Nights and One Night'', 1882–84). He, however, printed just 500 copies for private circulation and ceded the work to [[Richard Francis Burton]]. Burton's translation (''[[The Book of the Thousand Nights and a Night]]'', 1885–88) enjoyed a huge public success, but at the same time was criticized for its reportedly archaic language and excessive erotic details.<ref name="Marzolph 2004 507">{{harvnb|Marzolph|2004|p=507}}</ref> As of 2004, Burton's translation remains the most complete version of ''One Thousand and One Nights'' in English.<ref name="Marzolph 2004 507"/> It is also generally considered as one of the finest unexpurgated translations from Calcutta II.<ref>{{harvnb|Zipes|2007|p=57}}</ref> It stood as the only complete translation of the Macnaghten or Calcutta II edition (Egyptian recension) until the Malcolm C. and Ursula Lyons translation in 2008.
==German translations== In 1825 a Galland-based translation was made by [[Maximilian Habicht]]. Later, however, [[Duncan Black MacDonald]] showed that the Tunisian provenance of a manuscript Habicht claimed to use during the translation was a forgery which Habicht committed himself.<ref>{{cite book | editor=Ulrich Marzolph| title =The Arabian Nights in Transnational Perspective| publisher =Wayne State University Press | year =2007 | page =60 | isbn =0814332870}}</ref> In 1839–42 ''One Thousand and One Nights'' were translated into German by [[Gustav Weil]]. In 1895–97 [[Max Henning]] published another German translation in 24 small volumes; the first seven volumes were based on the Bulaq edition, while volumes 18–24 were largely translated from Richard Francis Burton. In 1912–13 another translation was made by [[Felix Paul Greve]].
In 1921–28 [[Enno Littmann]] produced a six-volume translation of the whole ''One Thousand and One Nights'' on the basis of Calcutta II into German, including the poetry. At the same time he translated one lewd portion into Latin, not German. Nonetheless, [[Isaak Filshtinsky]] considered Littmann's translation to be "the most complete and accomplished".<ref name="Salye"/> [[Robert Irwin (writer)|Robert Irwin]] called it "the best German translation".<ref>{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=13}}</ref>
==Dutch translations== There have been several Dutch translations made from the French editions of Galland and Mardrus.<ref>Richard van Leeuwen (1999). De wereld van Sjahrazaad. {{ISBN|9054602155}}.</ref> In 1999 the final volume of "De vertellingen van duizend-en-één nacht" was published; the first an so far only Dutch translation from the Arabic texts by Dr. Richard van Leeuwen. For his translation Van Leeuwen used the Bulaq-edition (Cairo 1835), the Calcutta-edition (1842) and the edition by Mahdi (Leiden 1984).<ref>http://bulaaq.nl/literatuur/105-de-vertellingen-van-duizend-en-een-nacht. Accessed 16 May 2017.</ref>
==Italian translation== In 1949 Arabist [[Francesco Gabrieli]], who headed the team of anonymous translators, produced the four-volume Italian translation, based on Bulaq collated with Calcutta II.
==Russian translations== {{multiple image | width = 125 | footer = Unpublished portion about erection and sexual intercourse from the Russian translation. This text, concerning night 584, was omitted in the 5th volume of ''One Thousand and One Nights'' published by [[Academia (publishing house)|Academia]] in 1933. There are 150 copies of this separate addendum. | image1 = 1001 Nights-Russian censored version-page I.tif | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = 1001 Nights-Russian censored version-page II.tif | alt2 = | caption2 = | image3 = 1001 Nights-Russian censored version-page III.tif | alt3 = | caption3 = }} The first Russian translation of ''One Thousand and One Nights'' was made by Alexey Filatyev in 1763–1774.<ref name="Salye"/> It was based on Galland's translation and consisted of 12 volumes.<ref name="Salye"/> Later Russian translations were also based on European translations. For instance, a three-volume translation by [[Yulia Doppelmayr]] (1889–1890) was based on Galland, the six-volume translation by [[Lyudmila Shelgunova]] (1894) was based on that by Edward William Lane and an anonymous translation (1902–1903) was based on Mardrus.<ref name="Salye"/>
The first Russian translation directly from the Arabic source (from Calcutta II) was made by [[Mikhail Salye]]<ref name="Salye"/> and published in eight volumes by [[Academia (publishing house)|Academia]] in 1929–1939. Salye also translated into Russian seven tales not contained in Calcutta II (from the manuscript in the [[National Library of Russia]]).<ref name="Salye"/>
==Spanish translations== The stories about [[Sinbad the Sailor]] were translated into Spanish already in 1253.<ref>{{harvnb|Irwin|2004|p=94}}</ref> Old Spanish translations were made particularly by Pedro Pedraza (from Galland), [[Vicente Blasco Ibáñez]] (from Mardrus), [[Eugenio Sanz del Valle]], and [[Luis Aguirre Prado]], [[Alfredo Domínguez]] (from Mardrus). More accurate translations were made by the Arabists [[Juan Vernet]] and [[Rafael Cansinos Asséns]].
==Chinese translations== A selection of stories from ''One Thousand and One Nights'', titled ''Yi Qian Lin Yi Ye'' appeared in 1900.<ref name="SOAS">{{cite web | url =http://eprints.soas.ac.uk/8331/1/The_Arabian_Nights_in_Chinese.pdf| title =The Arabian Nights in English and Chinese Translations: Differing Patterns of Cultural Encounter |publisher =[[SOAS, University of London]]|author=Wen-chin Ouyang| accessdate =20 Aug 2014}}</ref> In 1906 a four-volume translation was made by Xi Rou, published in Shanghai.
In the 1930 new translations, primarily from Bulaq, appeared under the title ''Yi Qian Lin Yi Ye''.<ref name="SOAS"/> In that period a five-volume translation by Na Xun was made. In the 1950s Na Xun produced another, three-volume translation titled ''Yi Qian Lin Yi Ye''.
In 1982 a six-volume Beijing edition of Na Xun was published. It became the source of the 1980s two-volume translation titled ''Tian Fang Ye Tan'', which appeared in [[Taipei]].<ref name="SOAS"/>
==Japanese translations== ''One Thousand and One Nights'' appeared in Japanese in as early as 1875 – the two-volume translation, made by {{nihongo||永峰秀樹|[[Hideki Nagamine]]}}, was titled {{nihongo||暴夜物語 : 開巻驚奇|Arabiya monogatari : Kaikan kyōki}} and published by {{nihongo||日本評論社|Nihon Hyōronsha}} in Tokyo. In the preface Nagamine wrote that he used G. F. Townsend's ''The Arabian Nights's Entertainments'', which was based on Jonathan Scott's English translation of Galland. Nagamine also used Edward William Lane's English translation as a supplement. The second Japanese translation by [[Inoue Tsutomu]], titled ''Zensekai ichidai kisho'' (''The Most Curious Book in the Whole World''), appeared in 1883 and became more popular than Nagamine's.<ref>{{harvnb|Nishio|Yamanaka|2006|p=120}}</ref>
Subsequently other Japanese translations were made, but the first complete Japanese translation from Arabic was published in 1976–92 by [[Shinji Maejima]] and [[Ikeda Osamu]], in nineteen volumes (titled ''Arabian Naito'').
==Hebrew translations== In the years 1947-1971 Arabist Yosef-Yoel Rivlin produced a 32-volume Hebrew translation, based mainly on Bulaq. A selection of stories, translated by Hanna Amit-Kohavi, appeared in two volumes, in the years 2008 and 2011, under the title ''Leylot Arav''.
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== *{{cite book |ref = harv| last =Zipes|first=Jack | title =When Dreams Came True: Classical Fairy Tales and Their Tradition| publisher =Taylor & Francis | year =2007 | isbn =0415980062}} *{{cite book | ref = harv|last = Marzolph | first =Ulrich| title =The Arabian Nights Encyclopedia| volume=1|publisher =ABC-CLIO| year =2004 | isbn =1576072045}} *{{cite book | ref = harv|last =Irwin | first =Robert | title =The Arabian Nights: A Companion| publisher =Tauris Parke Paperbacks | year = 2004| isbn =1860649831}} *{{cite book |ref = harv| last1= Nishio |first1=Tetsuo|last2 =Yamanaka|first2=Yuriko | title =Arabian Nights and Orientalism: Perspectives from East and West| publisher =I.B.Tauris | year = 2006| isbn =0857710508}}

The '''Tucson artifacts''', sometimes called the '''Tucson Lead Crosses''', '''Tucson Crosses''', '''Silverbell Road artifacts''', or '''Silverbell artifacts''', were thirty-one [[lead]] objects that Charles E. Manier and his family found in 1924 near [[Picture Rocks, Arizona]] which were initially thought by some to be created by early Mediterranean civilizations that had crossed the Atlantic in the first century, but were later determined to be a hoax.<ref name="Burgess"/><ref name="Feder">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Dubious Archaeology: From Atlantis to the Walam Olum|first=Kenneth L.|last=Feder|pages=257–258|year=2010|publisher=Greenwood|location=Santa Barbara, California|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RlRz2symkAsC&pg=PA257|accessdate=2011-11-01|isbn=9780313379192}}</ref>
The find consisted of thirty-one [[lead]] objects, including crosses, swords, and religious/ceremonial paraphernalia, most of which contained [[Hebrew]] or [[Latin]] engraved inscriptions, pictures of temples, leaders' portraits, angels, and a dinosaur (inscribed on the lead blade of a sword). One contained the phrase "Calalus, the unknown land," which was used by believers as the name of the settlement. The objects also have Roman numerals ranging from 790 to 900 inscribed on them, which were sometimes interpreted to represent the date of their creation. The site contains no other artifacts, no pottery [[sherd]]s, no broken glass, no human or animal remains, and no sign of hearths or housing.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology">Williams, Stephen (1991) ''Fantastic Archaeology: A Walk on the Wild Side of North American Prehistory'', University of Pennsylvania Press, Philadelphia.</ref><ref name="Burgess">Burgess, Don. (Spring 2009) [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-203330630.html "Romans in Tucson? The Story of an Archaeological Hoax."] ''Journal of the Southwest'' 51. 1. Retrieved February 23, 2013. {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref>
==History== On September 13, 1924 Charles Manier and his father stopped to examine some old lime kilns while driving northwest of Tucson on [[Silver Bell, Arizona|Silverbell Road]]. Manier saw an object protruding about {{convert|2|inch|cm}} from the soil. He dug it out, revealing that the object was a {{convert|20|inch|cm}}-long lead cross which weighed {{convert|64|lb}}. Between 1924 and 1930 additional objects were extracted from the [[caliche]], a layer of soil in which the soil particles have been cemented together by lime.<ref name=Thompson /><ref name=Erickson /> Caliche often takes a long period of time to form, but it can be made and placed around an article in a short period of time, according to a report written by James Quinlan, a retired Tucson geologist who had worked for the U.S. Geological Survey.<ref name="Burgess"/><ref>Burgess notes that Marshall Payn asked Quinlan to prepare his report for his article: Payn, Marshall. (1996) "The Tucson Artifacts: Case Closed." New England Antiquities Research Association Journal 30(3-4): 79-80.</ref> Quinlan also concluded that it would be easy to bury articles in the soft, silt material and associated caliche in the lime kiln where the objects were found at the margin of prior trenches.<ref name="Burgess"/> The objects were believed, by their discoverer and main supporters, to be of a Roman Judeo-Christian colony existing in what is now known as Arizona between 790–900 AD. No other find has been formally established as placing any Roman colony in the area, nor anywhere else in North America.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/>
In November 1924, Manier brought his friend Thomas Bent to the site and Bent was quickly convinced of the authenticity of the discovery. Upon finding the land was not owned, he immediately set up residence on the land in order to [[homestead (buildings)|homestead]] the property. Bent felt there was money to be made in further excavating the site.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/>
===Latin inscriptions===
The first object removed from the caliche by Manier was a crudely cast metal cross that weighed {{convert|62|lb}}; after cleaning it was revealed to be two separate crosses riveted together. After his find, Manier took the cross to Professor Frank H. Fowler, Head of the Department of Classical Languages at the [[University of Arizona]], at Tucson, who determined the language on the artifacts was Latin. He also translated one line as reading, "''Calalus, the unknown land''", from which the name of the supposed Latin colony was garnered.<ref name="Burgess"/>
The Latin inscriptions on the alleged artifacts supposedly record the conflicts of the leaders of Calalus against a barbarian enemy known as the "''Toltezus''", which some have interpreted as a supposed reference to the [[Mesoamerican]] [[Toltec]] civilization.<ref name="Burgess"/> However, the Latin on the artifacts appears to either be badly [[inflection|inflected]] original Latin, or inscriptions brazenly plagiarized from Classical authors such as [[Virgil]], [[Cicero]], [[Livy]], [[Cornelius Nepos]], and [[Horace]], among several others. This has led many experts to condemn the artifacts as frauds.<ref name="Burgess"/> What is perhaps most suspicious, however, is that most of the inscriptions are identical to what appeared in widely available Latin grammar books, like ''Harkness's Latin Grammar'' and ''Allen and Greenough's Latin Grammar'', as well as dictionaries like ''The Standard Dictionary of Facts''.<ref name="Burgess"/>
==Views on authenticity== Manier took the first item to the [[Arizona State Museum]] to be studied by archaeologist Karl Ruppert. Ruppert was impressed with the item, and went with Manier to the site the next day where he found a {{convert|7|lb}} caliche plaque with some inscriptions including an 800 AD date. A total of thirty-one objects were found.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/> Other contemporary scholars including George C. Valliant, a Harvard University archaeologist who visited the University of Arizona in 1928 and Bashford Dean, curator of arms and armor of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] in New York City thought the articles were fakes,<ref name="Burgess"/> Neil Merton Judd, curator of the National Museum at the [[Smithsonian Institution]] happened to be in Tucson at the time of the discovery of the objects and, after examining them, also thought they were fakes, proposing that they may have been created by "some mentally incompetent individual with a flair for old Latin and the wars of antiquity".<ref name="Burgess"/><ref>Gilstrap, Peter. (3/21/1996) [http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/1996-03-21/news/a-reputation-in-ruins/2/ 'A Reputation in Ruins'] ''Phoenix New Times''. Retrieved February 23, 2013.</ref>
===Supporters=== In the 1960s, Bent wrote a 350-page manuscript titled "The Tucson Artifacts" about the objects which is unpublished, but kept by the Arizona State Museum.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/> Both Manier and Bent were supporters of the objects as a genuine archaeological find.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/>
Lara Coleman Ostrander, a Tucson immigrant and high school history teacher studied the historical background of the research, and translated the alleged history of Calalus from the writings on the items. Geologist Clifton J. Sarle worked with Ostrander to present the Tucson Artifacts to the press and the academic profession.
Tucson University administrator and director of the Arizona State Museum Dean Byron Cummings led archaeologists at the university to the location where the items were found. He brought ten of the objects to the [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] and showing them at museums and universities on the east coast. Astronomer [[Andrew E. Douglass]], known for his work in [[dendrochronology]] also considered the items to be authentic.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/>
In 1975, [[Wake Forest University]] professor Cyclone Covey re-examined the controversy in his book titled ''Calalus: A Roman Jewish Colony in America from the Time of Charlemagne Through Alfred the Great''. Covey was in direct contact with Thomas Bent by 1970, and planned to carry out excavations at the site in 1972, but was not allowed, due to legal complications preventing Wake Forest University from leading a dig at the site.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/> Covey's book proposes that the objects are from a Jewish settlement, founded by people who came from Rome and settled outside of present day Tucson around 800 AD.<ref name=Erickson>{{cite news | url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:ADSB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0EACE604A615B05F&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FB3382EE6AD1E46 | title=Silverbell Road artifacts puzzle new generation | date=September 1, 1996 | agency=Arizona Daily Star | accessdate=February 23, 2013 | author=Erickson, Jim}}</ref>
===Skeptics=== Professor Frank Fowler originally translated the Latin inscriptions on the first items and found that the inscriptions were from well known classical authors such as [[Cicero]], [[Virgil]] and [[Horace]]. He researched local Latin texts available in Tucson at the time and found the inscriptions on the lead items to be identical to the texts available.
Dean Cumming's student and excavator, [[Emil Haury]], closely examined scratches on the surface of the objects as they were removed from the ground and concluded that they were planted, based partly on a cavity in the ground which was longer than a lead bar removed from it. After Cummings became president of the university, his views changed in an unclear manner, possibly due to Haury's skepticism, or the increasing sentiment that the items were nothing more than a hoax and as university president had to take a different stand on the matter. George M. B. Hawley staunchly opposed Bent's views about the objects. Hawley even accused Ostrander and Sarle as perpetrators of the hoax.<ref name="Fantastic Archaeology"/><ref name=Thompson>{{cite journal | title=Glimpses of the Young Emil Haury | author=Thompson, Raymond H. | journal=Journal of the Southwest | year=2004 | volume=46 | issue=1}}</ref>
===Possible creator=== A local news article identified Timotéo Odohui as the possible creator of the items. Odohui was a Mexican boy who lived near the site and was a sculptor. The article mentions his possible connection to the site and his ability to craft lead objects. Bent wrote that a craftsman in the area had recalled the boy, his love for sculpture of soft metals and his collection of books on foreign languages, and told the excavators this.<ref name=Erickson /><ref name="A Cold Trail">Stevens, Kristina (1990) "A Cold Trail," ''Zocalo Magazine'', Tucson.</ref>
==In popular culture== [[H. P. Lovecraft]] alludes to the Tucson artifacts in "[[The Mound (short story)|The Mound]]," a short story ghost-written for [[Zealia Bishop]].<ref>[[H. P. Lovecraft]]. "[[The Mound (short story)|The Mound]]". ([[wikisource:The_Mound/full|Wikisource]]) {{quote|The manuscript’s age looked appallingly genuine ... It must be a shocking hoax ... Surely this was the clever forgery of some learned cynic — something like the leaden crosses in New Mexico, which a jester once planted and pretended to discover as a relique of some forgotten Dark Age colony from Europe.}}</ref> Archaeologist and Lovecraft scholar Marc A. Beherec argues that the items influenced some of Lovecraft's other writings.<ref name="A Cold Trail"/><ref name="Lovecraft Roman Arizona">Beherec, Marc A. 2008. "H. P. Lovecraft and the Archaeology of 'Roman' Arizona." ''Lovecraft Annual'' 2: 192-202.</ref>
The Tucson artifacts were featured on [[The History Channel]] show ''[[America Unearthed]]'' in the episode titled "The Desert Cross," on February 22, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.history.com/shows/america-unearthed/season-1/episode-10 |work=America Unearthed |title=The Desert Cross |publisher=the History Channel |accessdate=December 16, 2016 |format=video}}</ref> This episode was criticised for its methodology, its ignorance (or deliberate omission) of the complete text on the crosses, and its conclusions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jasoncolavito.com/blog/review-of-america-unearthed-s01e10-the-desert-cross |first1=Jason |last1=Colavito |title=Review of America Unearthed S01E10 "The Desert Cross" |date=February 23, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Village Visit, Nguyet-Markbreiter collection.jpg|thumbnail|''Village Visit'', Anonymous. Late 18th/early 19th century, oil on glass. Nguyet-Markbreiter collection.]] '''Tuyet Nguyet''' ("Snow Moon") is the Vietnamese publisher, editor and founder of ''[[Arts of Asia]]'' magazine which has been published continuously since 1970. Nguyet conceived of the magazine after her brother was killed in the Vietnam War in 1969.
==Early life== Nguyet was born in [[Tan An]] province, Vietnam, near the [[Mekong River]] in the south of the country. Her name means "Snow Moon" in English. Nguyet's father had attended university in Paris and graduated with a degree in [[agronomy]]. He was responsible for the introduction of fertilisers on the French model into Vietnamese rice farming. Her mother was a school teacher.<ref name=sheaf>[http://images1.bonhams.com/original?src=Images/live/2014-08/29/S-22319-0-1.pdf "The Markbreiter Collection"] by Colin Sheaf in ''Art of Asia from the Tuyet Nguyet and Stephen Markbreiter Collection'', Bonhams, Hong Kong, 2014, p. 4.</ref>
Nguyet was educated at the [[Marie Curie High School|Lycee Maris Curie]] in Saigon. In 1955, she was awarded a scholarship to study Journalism at the [[Mundelein College]] in Chicago. She received her B.A. in journalism in 1958.<ref name=sheaf/>
==Marriage & Hong Kong== In 1959, Nguyet married [[Stephen Markbreiter]] (deceased), an English architect, and moved to Hong Kong.<ref name=nguyet>[http://images1.bonhams.com/original?src=Images/live/2014-08/29/S-22319-0-1.pdf "A Valedictory Editorial"] by Tuyet Nguyet Markbreiter in ''Art of Asia from the Tuyet Nguyet and Stephen Markbreiter Collection'', Bonhams, Hong Kong, 2014, p. 6.</ref> The couple had four sons between 1960 and 1969.<ref name=bridge/>
In Hong Kong, Nguyet developed her journalistic skills while writing for ''Asia Magazine'' (the Sunday magazine for the ''[[South China Morning Post]]''), the ''[[Far Eastern Economic Review]]'', ''[[Agence France Presse]]'', and ''[[Modern Asia]]''.<ref name=sheaf/>
==Asian arts== In 1969, after her brother was killed in the [[Vietnam War]], Nguyet began to plan a magazine about Asian arts and a preview edition of ''Arts of Asia'' magazine was published in 1970<ref name=bridge/> with the first regular edition appearing in 1971.<ref>[http://www.artsofasianet.com/about/about.php About us.] Arts of Asia. Retrieved 7 September 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.artsofasianet.com/publications/20100308.pdf "Arts of Asia Magazine 40th Anniversary Celebrations"] ''The Standard'', 8 March 2010, p. 1. [https://www.webcitation.org/6bNAkrUwq Archived here.]</ref> In the magazine, Nguyet sought to combine authoritative content from experts with detailed coverage of the Asian art market. Since its establishment the magazine has chronicled, through its saleroom reports and articles on collections and collectors, the expanding market for Asian art in Hong Kong. The executive editor of the magazine is Nguyet's son, [[Robin Markbreiter]].<ref name=bridge>[http://www.artsofasianet.com/publications/20060526.pdf "Arts of Asia Magazine"] Sponsored feature. Vicki Williams, ''[[South China Morning Post]]'', 24 May 2006, p. A13. [https://www.webcitation.org/6bN9tVdrr Archived here.]</ref>
In 2006, Nguyet helped to set up a vetting committee for the Asia International Arts & Antiques Fair (AIAA 2006) at the [[AsiaWorld-Expo]] in Hong Kong.<ref name=bridge/>
==Art collection== The Nguyet-Markbreiters formed an art collection from the early 1970s which was particularly strong in paintings on glass and mirrors. Parts of the collection were sold by Bonhams in Hong Kong in 2014.<ref>http://www.bonhams.com/auctions/22319/</ref>

{{Infobox coat of arms |name = Twelve Symbols national emblem |image = Twelve Symbols national emblem of China.svg |image_width = 300px |middle = |middle_width = |middle_caption = |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image9 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = [[File:Flag of the Empire of China 1915-1916.svg|border|20px]] [[Empire of China (1915–16)|Empire of China]] (1915–1916)
[[File:Flag of the Republic of China 1912-1928.svg|border|20px]] [[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republic of China]] (1913–1928) |year_adopted = February 1913 |crest = [[sun]], [[moon]] |torse = |shield = [[axe]] |supporters = [[dragon]], [[Phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]] |compartment = |motto = |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = 1913-1928 }} [[File:Commander-in-Chief_Flag_of_the_Republic_of_China_(Beiyang_Government).svg|thumb|Commander-in-Chief Flag of the Republic of China, 1912-1928]] The '''Twelve Symbols national emblem''' ({{zh|t=十二章國徽|p=Shí'èr zhāng Guóhuī}}) was the state emblem of the [[Empire of China (1915–1916)|Chinese Empire]] and the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Chinese Republic]] from 1913 to 1928. It was based on the ancient Chinese symbols of the [[Twelve Ornaments]]. == History == The Empire of China during the [[Manchu people|Manchu]]-led [[Qing dynasty]] did not have an official state emblem, but the flag featured the [[azure dragon]] on a plain yellow field with a red sun of the [[three-legged crow]]{{cn|date=July 2017}} in the upper left corner. It became the first national flag of China and is usually referred to as the [[Flag of the Qing dynasty|Yellow Dragon Flag]]. Following the end of Manchu rule, new national symbols were deemed necessary by the leaders to represent the changed circumstances. The renowned writers [[Lu Xun]], [[Qian Daosun]], and [[Xu Shoushang]] from the [[Ministry of Education (Republic of China)|Ministry of Education]] were tasked with designing a new national emblem. It was presented on August 28, 1912 and was adopted as national emblem in February 1913. President-Emperor [[Yuan Shikai]] continued its use during his short imperial reign from 1915 to 1916. Coins issued during this time feature the emblem.http://coin007.com/bbs/read.php?tid=34187http://home.netvigator.com/~ykleungn/phoenix.htm A variation of the emblem was shown on orders and illustrations.http://www.guokr.com/blog/151573/?page=2 The [[Northern Expedition]] led by General [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and the [[Kuomintang]] party led to the overthrow of the fractious but legitimate [[Beiyang government]] in 1928. This ushered in a [[one-party state]] under the Kuomintang known as the [[Nanjing decade]]. The state emblem was therefore replaced with the Kuomintang party symbol [[Blue Sky with a White Sun]]. == Design == [[File:Douze emblemes des rites memoires historiques V3c23 205.PNG|thumb|]] [[File:Douze emblemes des rites memoires historiques V3c23 204.PNG|thumb|]] The emblem is based on the ancient symbols of the [[Twelve Ornaments]].[http://www.douban.com/note/122173887/ Description of proposed national emblem to the state council] - [[Lu Xun]], February 1913 These are first mentioned as already ancient in the ''[[Book of Documents]]'' by [[Emperor Shun]], who was one of the legendary [[Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors]]. Oral tradition holds that he lived sometime between 2294 and 2184 BCE.{{cite book |first=C.A.S |last=Williams|date=2001 |title=Chinese Symbolism and Art Motifs |edition=4th |publisher=[[Tuttle Publishing]] |isbn=0-8048-3704-X |pages=386 |ref=harv}} According to the book, the emperor wished for the symbols to be used on official robes of the state. The symbols were considered most auspicious and therefore as a set were reserved only for the emperor to be shown on his ceremonial robes.{{sfnp|Williams|2001|p=387}} The national emblem arranges these symbols in such a way to reflect the order of [[achievement (heraldry)|achievement]] in western [[heraldry]]. == Symbols == *The [[dexter and sinister|supporter sinister]] is a dragon, which symbolizes strength and adaptability. The [[azure dragon]] already featured on the national flag during the preceding Qing dynasty. *On the back of the dragon is fire, which symbolises light and brightness. *Behind the head of the dragon is the crescent [[moon]] of the [[moon rabbit]] who is constantly pounding the [[elixir of life]]. *The [[dexter and sinister|supporter dexter]] is a ''[[fenghuang]]'', or pheasant-phoenix, and represents peace and refinement. *The phoenix holds [[pondweed]] or algae in its right talon, a symbol of purity and brightness. *Behind its head are three stars, which could be the ''[[Fu Lu Shou]]'' stars, which symbolise happiness, prosperity and longevity. *Both creatures hold in one of each claws the ''zongyi'' ({{zh|宗彝}}), which is a sacrificial cup, symbolising devotion and loyalty. The dragon and phoenix represent the natural world. In [[yin and yang]] terminology, a dragon is male ''yang'' and the phoenix a female ''yin''. Therefore, the emperor was often identified as the dragon, while the empress was the phoenix. The inclusion of the phoenix into the national symbol, opposite but equal to the dragon, can be seen as a symbol of women being equal to men, and a visual and poignant representation of women's rights in the new China. *Featuring as the [[crest (heraldry)|crest]] on top is an abstract symbol of the [[sun]] of the [[three-legged crow]]. *In the middle functioning as the [[escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheon]] is the [[axe]] head, which symbolises courage and resolution, but also executive justice. The blade of the axe head is pointing downwards, the head is shaped like a sloping mountain. *Overlaid on the axe head are grains of rice, which symbolise nourishment and the country's agriculture. It can also be seen as a symbol of the concept of a [[moderately prosperous society]]. *In the center of the axe head framed by a [[pentagon]] is a simplified symbol of a rice [[Ear (botany)|ear]], which again stresses the importance of agriculture as the basis of the country's wealth and prosperity. The shape on the emblem is based on a carved stone dating to the [[Han dynasty]]. *The downward-pointing blade of the axe head features a [[differential heat treatment|hardened edge]] in shape of the four [[Sacred Mountains of China|sacred mountains]]. These represent tranquility and steadiness. The fifth Center Great Mountain is represented by the axe head. The mountains represent earth, the cups metal, the pondweed water, the rice grains wood, and fire, which are all representations of ''[[wu xing]]''. *The figure 亞 ''fu'' underneath the axe represents two animals with their backside together. This symbolises the capability to make a clear distinction between right and wrong. *The ''fu'' sign is in the middle of complex interlacing ribbons, which connect the dragon, the phoenix and the axe to each other. The ribbons could symbolise [[Great Unity]] and [[Harmonious Society]]. == See also == {{Portal|China|Heraldry}} * [[Five Races Under One Union]] national flag * ''[[Song to the Auspicious Cloud]]'' national anthem == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{China topics}} {{Coats of arms of Asia}} [[Category:National emblems|China]] [[Category:National symbols of China]] [[Category:National symbols of the Republic of China]] [[Category:Coats of arms with dragons]]

{{Infobox video game | title = Twin Mirror | image = Twin Mirror.jpg | developer = [[Dontnod Entertainment]] | publisher = [[Bandai Namco Entertainment]] | engine = | platforms = {{ubl|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = {{ubl|'''Episode 1'''|2019}} | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | producer = Fabrice Cambounet<ref name="Romano-Aug2018" /> | programmer = | designer = | artist = Pierre-Etienne Travers<ref name="Romano-Sep2018" /> | writer = Matthew Ritter<ref name="DONTNOD-Aug2018-A" /> | composer = }}
'''''Twin Mirror''''' is an upcoming episodic [[adventure game]] developed by [[Dontnod Entertainment]] and published by [[Bandai Namco Entertainment]], releasing in 2019 for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Xbox One]].
==Gameplay== ''Twin Mirror'' is an [[adventure game]] played from a [[third-person view]].<ref name="Oloman-Jun2018" /><ref name="Siliconera-Jul2018" /> Players control the investigative journalist Sam, who has returned to his hometown of Basswood, [[West Virginia]].<ref name="BandaiNamcoEntertainment-Jun2018" /> The environment is interactive and its objects are obtainable.<ref name="IGN-Aug2018" /> Whom Sam speaks to is optional and, based on the state of his investigation, there are multiple endings to unlock.<ref name="Siliconera-Jul2018" /> Players navigate between the real world and Sam's "[[Mind Palace]]" to discover clues. Sam's inner voice, the Double, may aid or harm the investigation.<ref name="Romano-Aug2018" />
==Development== Partnering with publisher [[Bandai Namco]], [[Dontnod Entertainment]] began developing ''Twin Mirror'' in 2016 with a separate team of senior developers.<ref name="Byrne-Aug2017" /> About forty people were working on it as of September 2018.<ref name="Metro-Sep2018" /> Lead writer Matthew Ritter was influenced by adventure games like ''[[Beneath a Steel Sky]]'' and ''[[Space Quest]]''.<ref name="DONTNOD-Aug2018-B" /> Contrary to previous titles, Dontnod desired to have ''Twin Mirror'' be void of any supernatural elements.<ref name="Metro-Sep2018" /> According to art director Pierre-Etienne Travers, the game's primary concept is [[Mind–body dualism|duality]].<ref name="Smith-Oct2018" /> The decision to set it in a fictional American town, based on southern [[West Virginia]], was to broaden its appeal.<ref name="Byrne-Aug2017" /><ref name="Smith-Oct2018" />
==Release== ''Twin Mirror'' was announced with a debut trailer in June 2018, set to be released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], and [[Xbox One]] the following year.<ref name="McWhertor-Jun2018" /> It was later revealed that it would be an episodic title, with ''Lost on Arrival'' as the first of three.<ref name="Barker-Aug2018" />

[[ZX Spectrum]] }} '''''Vendetta''''' is a 1989 [[beat 'em up]] [[video game]] released by [[Studio 3|System 3]] for the [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Commodore 64]], and [[ZX Spectrum]]. == Plot == A group of terrorists have kidnapped a professor working on a bomb as well as his daughter. A few weeks later, they have started to make impossible demands and have threatened to detonate a miniature nuclear weapon if the demands are not met. The protagonist, initially armed with only a knife, decides to rescue both individuals. Along the way, he collects other weapons and evidence to convince other police officers to let him continue his work, as he heads to an army base, a booby-trapped airplane, and finally central park where the terrorists make the last stand. == Development == ''Vendetta'' was based on the same rendering method and display used by ''[[The Last Ninja]]'', but used a rewritten engine. This game engine was then used for the game ''[[Last Ninja 3]]''.[http://lastninja.lemon64.com/updates_old.php Last Ninja fan page], "The Vendetta engine was written from scratch and then used as the basis for LN3." == Acclaim == Vendetta received 93% from ''[[Zzap!64]]''.[http://www.zzap64.co.uk/cgi-bin/displaypage.pl?issue=058&page=016&thumbstart=0&magazine=zzap&check=1 ZZap 64 Issue February 1990, page 016] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:1991 video games]] [[Category:Amstrad CPC games]] [[Category:Beat 'em ups]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:Terrorism in fiction]] [[Category:Video games with isometric graphics]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:ZX Spectrum games]] {{8bitcomputer-game-stub}}

In the broadest sense of the word, a '''vocable''' is any meaningful sound uttered by people, such as a word or term, that is fixed by their language and culture.<ref>{{OED|vocable}}</ref><ref>''The Cambridge Companion to Saussure''</ref> However, use in the broad sense is archaic. The term is currently used for utterances which are not considered [[word]]s, such as the English vocables of assent and denial, ''uh-huh'' {{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|h|ʌ}} and ''uh-uh'' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʌ|ʔ|ə}}, or the vocable of error, ''uh-oh'' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʌ|ʔ|oʊ}}.<ref>Danesi (2004) ''A Basic Course in Anthropological Linguistics''</ref>
Such non-lexical vocables are often [[Non-lexical vocables in music|used in music]], for example ''la la la'' or ''dum dee dum'', or in magical incantations, such as ''abra-cadabra''. Many [[Native American music|Native American songs]] consist entirely of vocables; this may be due to both phonetic substitution to increase the [[Sonorant|resonance]] of the song, and to the trade of songs between nations speaking different languages.<ref>Golla (2011) ''California Indian Languages'', §4.12.4</ref>
Vocables are common as [[pause filler]]s, such as ''um'' and ''er'' in English, where they have little formal meaning and are rarely purposeful.
[[Pseudoword]]s that mimic the structure of real words are used in experiments in [[psycholinguistics]] and [[cognitive psychology]], for example the [[nonsense syllable]]s introduced by [[Hermann Ebbinghaus]].
The [[Babbling|proto-word]]s of infants, which are meaningful but do not correspond to words of adult speech, are also sometimes called vocables.<ref>Crystal (2008) ''A Dictionary of Linguistics and Phonetics''</ref>

[[File:The Bard (1774).jpeg|thumb|350px|''The Bard'', 1774, by [[Thomas Jones (artist)|Thomas Jones]] (1742–1803)]]
'''Welsh art''' refers to the traditions in the [[visual arts]] associated with [[Wales]] and [[Welsh people|its people]]. Most art found in, or connected with, Wales is essentially a regional variant of the forms and styles of the rest of the [[British Isles]], a very different situation from that of [[Welsh-language literature|Welsh literature]]. The term '''Art in Wales''' is often used in the absence of a clear sense of what "Welsh art" is, and to include the very large body of work, especially in [[landscape art]], produced by non-Welsh artists in Wales (or with a Welsh subject) since the later 18th century.<ref>Houseley explores the lack of a clear sense of "Welsh art" among contemporary artists and in Wales generally. See also Morgan, 371–372.</ref>
==Early history== [[File:British Museum gold thing 501594 fh000035.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The gold [[Mold Cape]], [[Bronze Age]], 1900–1600 BC]] [[Prehistoric Wales]] has left a number of significant finds: [[Kendrick's Cave]], [[Llandudno]] contained the [[Kendrick's Cave Decorated Horse Jaw]], "a decorated horse jaw which is not only the oldest known work of art from Wales but also unique among finds of [[Ice Age art]] from Europe", and is now in the [[British Museum]].<ref>Kendrick's Cave [https://www.britishmuseum.org/whats_on/touring_exhibitions_and_loans/sharing_the_treasures.aspx BM touring exhibition], [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/d/decorated_horse_jaw.aspx BM Highlights]</ref> In 2011 "faint scratchings of a speared reindeer" were found on a cave wall on the [[Gower peninsula]] which probably date to 12,000–14,000 BC, placing them among the earliest art found in Britain.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-14272126 "Carving found in Gower cave could be oldest rock art"], BBC News online, South-West Wales, July 25, 2011</ref> The [[Mold Gold Cape]], also in the British Museum, and [[Banc Ty'nddôl sun-disc]] in the [[National Museum of Wales]] in [[Cardiff]] are likewise some of the most important British works of art from the [[Bronze Age]].
Many works of [[Iron Age]] [[Celtic art]] have been found in Wales.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1938/ | title=Celtic Art in Iron Age Wales| work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=3 May 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> and the finds from the period shortly before and after the Roman conquest, which reached Wales in AD 74-8, are especially significant. Pieces of metalwork from [[Llyn Cerrig Bach]] on [[Anglesey]] and other sites exemplify the final stages of [[La Tène style]] in the British Isles, and the [[Capel Garmon Firedog]] is a spectacular luxury piece of [[ironwork]], among the finest in Europe from the period.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1940/ | title=Stunning ironwork firedog uncovered in farmers field | work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=4 May 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> The [[Abergavenny Leopard Cup]], from the decades after the conquest, was found in 2003, and shows the presence of imported Roman luxury products in Wales, perhaps belonging to a soldier.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1951/ | title=Exquisite Roman treasure gives up its secrets | work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=9 September 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Ricemarch Psalter, Psalm 1.JPG|thumb|upright|right|The [[Ricemarch Psalter]], c. 1080, the start of Psalm 1:"Beatus vir..."]]
In the [[Early Medieval]] period, the [[Celtic Christianity]] of Wales participated in the [[Insular art]] of the British Isles and a number of [[illuminated manuscript]]s [[:Category:Illuminated manuscripts of Welsh origin|possibly of Welsh origin]] survive, of which the 8th century [[Hereford Gospels]] and [[Lichfield Gospels]] are the most notable. The 11th century [[Ricemarch Psalter]] (now in [[Dublin]]) is certainly Welsh, made in [[St David's]], and shows a late Insular style with unusual [[Viking]] influence, which is also seen in surviving pieces of metalwork of that period.
There are only fragments of the architecture of the period remaining. Unlike Irish [[high cross]] and [[Pictish stones]], early Welsh standing stones mainly employ geometric patterns and words, rather than figure representation; however, 10th century stones represent Christ and various saints. Little metalwork survives from the early period of the 5th–9th centuries in Wales. However, archaeological sites at Dinas Powys have revealed various artifacts such as [[penannular brooch]]es and other pieces of jewellery. Similar brooches have been discovered a site at Penycorddyn-mawr, near [[Abergele]], dating to the 8th century. During this period, the construction of [[Holy well]]s was also particularly commonplace in Wales.
Wales has rarely been very prosperous, and the most striking medieval architecture is military, often built by the Normans and English, especially the famous "[[Castles and Town Walls of King Edward in Gwynedd]]" and [[Beaumaris Castle]] in [[Anglesey]], recognised as [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]s, [[Caerphilly Castle]] and the castles of the Welsh Prince Llywelyn the Great (such as [[Criccieth Castle]] and [[Dolbadarn Castle]]). There are a number of impressive [[List of abbeys and priories in Wales|monastic ruins]]; Welsh medieval churches are nearly all relatively modest, including the cathedrals. They very often had wall-paintings, panel altarpieces and much other religious art, but as in the rest of Britain very little has survived. [[Conwy]], an English garrison town with its medieval walls almost entirely intact, has a notable example of a 13th-century medieval stone town-house.
==The Renaissance in Wales== [[Peter Lord (art historian)|Peter Lord]] suggests that the Renaissance began in Wales around 1400.<ref>[http://www.southwales-eveningpost.co.uk/Art-historian-Peter-Lord-talks-new-book-Tradition/story-28873873-detail/story.html "Art historian Peter Lord talks The Tradition: A New History of Welsh Art: "It's a book for everyone" ", ''South Wales Evening Post'', 7 March 2016]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> Much of the art produced in this period was created in or for the church. [[Strata Florida Abbey]], for example, retains some of its medieval decorated tiles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cadw.gov.wales/daysout/strata-florida-abbey/?lang=en|title=Strata Florida Abbey|website=Cadw|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref>
Despite the widespread destruction that took place during the Reformation and later the Commonwealth, a number of Welsh churches retain fragments of medieval [[stained glass]]. These include [[All Saints' Church, Gresford]], St Michael's Church, [[Caerwys]], St Mary's Church, [[Treuddyn]], St Elidan's Church, [[Llanelidan]], Church of St Mary & St Nicholas, [[Beaumaris]], St Gwyddelan's Church, [[Dolwyddelan]], and [[St David's Cathedral]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stainedglass.llgc.org.uk/main.php?func=nextpage&terms=&page=3|title=Medieval fragments|website=Stained Glass in Wales|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref>
Fifteenth-century wall paintings have been uncovered in several Welsh church buildings, including St Cadoc's Church, [[Llancarfan]],<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-25214557 "Welsh church uncovers stunning medieval wall paintings", BBC News, 6 December 2013]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> [[St Illtyd's Church, Llantwit Major]] (which has a painting of [[Saint Christopher]] believed to date from around 1400),<ref>{{cite web|last=Llantwit Major Historical Society|title=St. Illtud's Church|url=http://www.llantwitmajorhistorysociety.co.uk/#/st-illtuds-church/4565870953|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> and [[St Teilo's Church, Llandeilo Tal-y-bont]]. The latter, during its reconstruction at [[St Fagans National History Museum]] during the 1990s, was found to contain wall paintings from several different periods, the earliest estimated as being from the first half of the fifteenth century.<ref>[http://www.buildingconservation.com/articles/medieval-wall-paintings/medieval-wall-paintings.htm Tom Organ, "Reconstructing Medieval Wall Paintings at St Teilo's", www.building.conservation.com]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> The wall paintings at Llancarfan are said to be "beyond compare in Wales".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/mind-blowing-medieval-art-unveiled-church-1888480|title='Mind-blowing’ medieval art is unveiled in church|author=Claire Miller|website=WalesOnline|date=28 March 2013|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref> [[File:Miss Catherine Jones of Colomendy, near Mold - Richard Wilson.jpg|thumb|Rare portrait by [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]], of his cousin Miss Catherine Jones of Colomendy, c. 1740]]
[[Plas Mawr]], a grand Elizabethan town-house in Conwy, built by [[Robert Wynn (MP)|Robert Wynn]], a local man who had been English ambassador to the [[Holy Roman Emperor]], has been extensively restored by [[Cadw]], both inside and out, to reflect its appearance when built in the second half of the sixteenth century.<ref>[http://cadw.gov.wales/daysout/plasmawr/?lang=en Cadw: Plas Mawr]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> Wales has numerous country houses from all periods after the Elizabethan, many still containing good portraits, but these were mostly painted in London or on the Continent.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/galleries/faces/ "Faces of Wales" from the National Museum of Wales]</ref>
==Portraiture== Within Wales, [[portraiture]] is not common in the medieval and post-medieval periods, and the Welsh nobility and gentry usually went to London or other English centres to have their portraits painted; many of these remain in Welsh collections. [[Katheryn of Berain]],<ref>[https://www.museumwales.ac.uk/articles/2011-10-10/Katheryn-of-Berain/ National Museum of Wales: Katheryn of Berain]. Accessed 2 April 2016</ref> who claimed Tudor ancestry and earned the nickname "Mam Gymru" ("Mother of Wales") because of her network of relationships and descendants from four marriages, was painted by [[Adriaen van Cronenburgh]], a Dutch painter. The portrait was commissioned by her husband, Sir [[Richard Clough]], a merchant whose business caused the couple to settle briefly in Antwerp. Clough himself died before he could bring his wife to the new house he had built for her. Plas Clough, near his home town of Denbigh, includes a Flemish-style crow-stepped gable<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-1064-plas-clough-denbigh#.VwFSNnarSM8 British Listed Buildings: Plas Clough, Denbigh]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> The arms of the Holy Sepulchre (Clough had been made a [[Knight of the Holy Sepulchre]] earlier in his career) are painted on a plaque, but there are no surviving contemporary portraits of Clough himself.
[[William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (died 1570)]], was one of the first Welsh nobles known to have collected paintings on a large scale. A portrait of him, dating from the 1560s, is held by the [[National Museum of Wales]]; it is attributed to [[Steven van Harwijck]], another Dutch artist.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_item&item=9 National Museum of Wales - William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref>
Later, artisan painters such as [[William Roos]] and [[Hugh Hughes (painter)|Hugh Hughes]] began to seek portrait commissions.<ref>[https://www.llgc.org.uk/collections/learn-more/portraits/paintings-and-drawings/ National Library of Wales: Paintings and Drawings]. Accessed 18 April 2016</ref> Roos's 1835 portrait of preacher [[Christmas Evans]] is held by the [[National Museum of Wales]], as is Hughes' 1826 portrait of [[William Jenkins Rees]].<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_works&item=379&type=artist Art Collections Online: Hugh Hughes]. National Museum of Wales. Accessed 18 April 2016</ref>
==Landscapes== [[File:Richard Wilson - Snowdon from Llyn Nantlle - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Snowdon]] from [[Llyn Nantlle Uchaf|Llyn Nantlle]]'', [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]], c. 1766]] The best of the few Welsh artists of the 16th to 18th centuries tended to move elsewhere to work, but in the 18th century the dominance of [[landscape art]] in [[English art]] brought them motives to stay at home, and brought an influx of artists from outside to paint Welsh scenery, which was "discovered" by artists rather earlier than later landscape hotspots like the English [[Lake District]] and the [[Scottish Highlands]]. The Welsh painter [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]] (1714–1782) is arguably the first major British landscapist, but rather more notable for Italian scenes than Welsh ones, although he did paint several on visits from London.
Wilson's pupil [[Thomas Jones (artist)|Thomas Jones]] (1742–1803), has a rather higher status today than in his own time, but mainly for his city scenes painted in Italy, though his ''The Bard'' (1774, Cardiff) is a classic work showing the emerging combination of the [[Celtic Revival]] and [[Romanticism]].<ref>[http://www.museum.ac.uk/en/2261/ NMOW, Welsh Artists of the 18th Century]. Though mainly known as a portraitist, [[John Downman]], born and died in Wales, is also noted for unusually realistic Italian townscape studies, and some Welsh landscapes.</ref> He returned to live in Wales on inheriting the family estate, but largely stopped painting. For most visiting artists the main attraction was dramatic mountain scenery, in the new taste for the [[Sublime (literary)|sublime]] partly stimulated by [[Edmund Burke]]'s ''[[A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful]]'' (1757), though some earlier works were painted in Wales in this strain.<ref>Rosenthal, 52–64</ref> Early works tended to see the Welsh mountains through the prism of the 17th century Italianate "wild" landscapes of [[Salvator Rosa]] and [[Gaspard Dughet]].<ref>Rosenthal, 56</ref> [[File:A Welsh Sunset River Landscape by Paul Sandby, RA.jpg|thumb|''A Welsh Sunset River Landscape'' by [[Paul Sandby]], showing rather better weather than most "sublime" landscapes]]
By the 1770s a number of guide books had been published, including Joseph Cradock's ''Letters from Snowdon'' (1770) and ''An Account of Some of the Most Romantic Parts of North Wales'' (1777). [[Thomas Pennant]] wrote ''Tour in Wales'' (1778) and ''Journey to [[Snowdon]]'' (1781/1783); though Welsh himself, Pennant had published a ''Tour in Scotland'' first, in 1769.<ref>Rosenthal, 61</ref> The first of a series of British tours by another leading promoter of the picturesque, [[William Gilpin (clergyman)|William Gilpin]], was ''Observations on the River Wye and several parts of South Wales, etc. relative chiefly to Picturesque Beauty; made in the summer of the year 1770'', but not published until 1782. [[Paul Sandby]] made his first recorded visit to [[Wales]] in 1770, later (1773) touring south Wales with Sir [[Joseph Banks]], resulting in the 1775 publication of ''XII Views in South Wales'' and a further 12 views the following year, part of a 48-plate series of [[aquatint]]s of Welsh views commissioned by Banks. This was an early example of many print series and illustrated books on Wales, often as valuable in terms of income to the artists as original works.
[[File:Joseph Wright of Derby. Landscape near Bedgellert, North Wales.c.1790-5.jpg|thumb|left|[[Joseph Wright of Derby]], ''Landscape near [[Beddgelert]], North Wales'', {{circa|1790–5}}]]
What might fifty years earlier have been merely regarded as inconvenience in travel could now been seen as an exciting adventure worth making the subject of a painting, as in [[Julius Caesar Ibbetson]]'s ''[[Phaeton (carriage)|Phaeton]] in a Thunderstorm'' (1798, now [[Temple Newsam]], Leeds) which shows a carriage struggling up a rough mountain road. It has a label on the back by the artist, recording that the incident occurred when he was travelling in Wales with the artist [[John "Warwick" Smith]] and the aristocrat [[Robert Fulke Greville]].<ref>Rosenthal, 52 & 54. [http://www.artchive.com/web_gallery/reproductions//235001-235500/235144/size1.jpg Image of ''[[Phaeton (carriage)|Phaeton]] in a Thunderstorm'']</ref> Ibbetson visited Wales often, and was also one of the first artists to record the Welsh [[Industrial Revolution]], and scenes of Welsh life.
North Wales tended to be more visited; the young [[watercolour]]ist [[John Sell Cotman]] embarked on his "first extended sketching tour" in 1800, starting from Bristol then following "a well-trodden path into the [[Wye Valley]], through [[Brecknockshire]] to [[Llandovery]] and north to [[Aberystwyth]]. In Conway he joined a group of artists gathered around the amateur [[Sir George Beaumont, 7th Baronet|Sir George Beaumont]]" perhaps meeting [[Thomas Girtin]] there, and continuing to [[Caernarfon|Caernarvon]] and [[Llangollen]]. A second trip followed in 1802; he continued to use motifs from his sketches throughout his career.<ref>Holcomb, 8</ref> Other artists often in Wales in this period included [[Francis Towne]], the brothers [[Cornelius Varley|Cornelius]] and [[John Varley (painter)|John Varley]] and John's pupils [[Copley Fielding]] and David Cox (for whose lifelong attachment to Wales see below). Even the caricaturist [[Thomas Rowlandson]] visited with [[Henry Wigstead]], a colleague, and they published ''Remarks on a Tour to North and South Wales, in the Year 1797'', an illustrated book.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/remarksonatourt00wigsgoog|title=Remarks on a Tour to North and South Wales: In the Year 1797|first=Henry|last=Wigstead|year=1800|publisher= W. Wigstead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite ODNB|id=24221 |title=Rowlandson, Thomas|first=John|last=Hayes}}</ref>
The French Revolutionary and [[Napoleonic War]]s made continental travel impossible for long periods, increasing the visitors to Wales and other parts of Britain. The young [[J. M. W. Turner]] made his first extended tour to South and mid-Wales in 1792, followed by North Wales in 1794, and a seven-week tour of Wales in 1798. He also visited Yorkshire and Scotland in the 1790s, but was unable to visit Europe until after the [[Treaty of Amiens]] in 1802, when he reached the [[Alps]]; he did not visit Italy until 1819.<ref>Wilton & Lyles, 326-7</ref> Many of his key early works drew on his Welsh travels, although they were painted back in London. His "first large classicising watercolour, a [[Claude Lorrain|Claudeian]] view of [[Caernarvon Castle]] at sunset" was exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] in 1799, along with an oil of the same subject, and the next year he showed another view of the castle, this time with small foreground figures of "a [[bard]] singing to his followers of the destruction of Welsh civilization by the invading armies of [[Edward I of England|Edward I]]", another Claudeian formula that he was to repeat many times in major works for the rest of his career, and was arguably the first large "exhibition watercolour", reaching into the realm of [[history painting]].<ref>Wilton & Lyles,pp. 176 & 260. Respectively: Private Collection, Mellon Centre for British Art, Tate.</ref>
==Expansion== [[File:Cox - A WELSH FUNERAL.jpg|thumb|left|[[David Cox (artist)|David Cox]], ''A Welsh Funeral'', c. 1850]] It remained difficult for artists relying on the Welsh market to support themselves until well into the 20th century. The 1851 census records only 136 people describing their occupation as "artist" out of a population of 945,000, with a further 50 engaged in [[fine arts]]-related occupations such as [[engraving]].<ref>Harvey, John, ''The art of piety: the visual culture of Welsh Nonconformity'', p.75, University of Wales Press, 1995, {{ISBN|0-7083-1298-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7083-1298-8}}</ref> An [[Act of Parliament]] in 1857 provided for the establishment of a number of art schools throughout the United Kingdom, and the [[University of Wales Institute, Cardiff|Cardiff School of Art]] opened in 1865. Prior to that the annual report for 1855 of the government [[Science and Art Department]] shows a list of the larger type of Art School in many British cities, but none in Wales.<ref>1855, Table p. xxii</ref> Under a recently introduced new system "Local Schools of Art" had been established in 1853 in [[Llanelly]] and [[Merthyr]], but had already closed; those in [[Swansea]] and [[Carmarthen]] continued, and [[Flint, Flintshire|Flint]] had applied to establish a school. There were "Drawing Schools" in [[Aberdare]] and [[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]], but apparently nothing at all in Cardiff.<ref>1855, Appendix A, pp. 21–26</ref> However all these pre-1857 schools, except perhaps Swansea, were mainly teaching school age children, usually in their normal schools, and training in industrial design or teacher-training under the elementary stages of the "[[South Kensington system]]".<ref>1855, pp. xxii–xxx</ref> [[File:Mansel Lewis - Snowdonia.jpg|thumb|Mansel Lewis, ''[[Snowdonia]]'']]
Graduates of the new fine arts Welsh colleges still very often had to leave Wales to work. Established artists continued to move in the opposite direction, at least for the summer. [[David Cox (artist)|David Cox]] was an English 19th century landscapist who spent much time in Wales, for many years spending the summer based in [[Betws-y-Coed]], a popular centre for artists, including the English [[Henry Clarence Whaite]] and the German [[Hubert von Herkomer]], one of whose wives was Welsh. Landscape continued to be the main focus, although the Welsh artist [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Mansel_Lewis Charles William Mansel Lewis] was among those who painted common working people, with varying measures of realism or picturesqueness. The "Betws-y-Coed artist's colony" was one of the groups forming the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art]] in 1881; this was always a group for exhibiting rather than a teaching institution, based in Conwy, until 1994 in Plas Mawr (see above).[[File:Walescw.jpg|thumb|upright|left|''Deffroad Cymru, the Awakening of Wales'' (1911), by [[Christopher Williams (Welsh artist)|Christopher Williams]] (1873–1934)]] <ref>[http://www.rcaconwy.org/our_history-5.aspx Royal Cambrian Academy]</ref> The sculptors [[John Evan Thomas (Welsh sculptor)|John Evan Thomas]] (1810–1873) and Sir William [[Goscombe John]] (1860–1952) made many works for Welsh commissions, although they had settled in London. Even [[Christopher Williams (Welsh artist)|Christopher Williams]] (1873–1934), whose subjects were mostly resolutely Welsh, was based in London. [[Thomas E. Stephens]] (1886–1966) and [[Andrew Vicari]] (b. 1938) had very successful careers as portraitists based respectively in the United States and France. Sir [[Frank Brangwyn]] was Welsh by origin, but spent little time in Wales.
Perhaps the most famous Welsh-born painters were [[Augustus John]] and his sister [[Gwen John]], though they mostly lived in London and Paris; however the landscapists Sir [[Kyffin Williams]] (1918–2006) and [[Peter Prendergast (artist)|Peter Prendergast]] (1946–2007) remained living in Wales for most of their lives, though well in touch with the wider art world. [[Ceri Richards]] was very engaged in the Welsh art scene as a teacher in Cardiff, and even after moving to London; he was a figurative painter in international styles including [[Surrealism]]. Various artists have moved to Wales, usually the countryside, though paintings of [[Cardiff]] of around 1893–97 by the American artist [[Lionel Walden]] are in museums in Cardiff and Paris.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/art/online/?action=show_item&item=1860 National Museum of Wales, Walden]</ref> These included [[Eric Gill]], whose colony included for his most artistically productive period (1924–1927) the London-born Welshman [[David Jones (poet)|David Jones]], and the sculptor [[Jonah Jones (sculptor)|Jonah Jones]]. [[The Kardomah Gang]] was an intellectual circle centred on the poet [[Dylan Thomas]] and poet and artist [[Vernon Watkins]] in Swansea, which also included the painter [[Alfred Janes]]; the eponymous cafe was destroyed by a German bomb in 1941.
The situation gradually improved after World War II, with the appearance of new art groups. ''The South Wales Group'' was established in 1948 (and continues today as [[The Welsh Group]] with membership from across Wales).<ref name="The Welsh Group">[http://www.thewelshgroup-art.com/#!about-amdanom/ciaa] The Welsh Group website. Retrieved 2015-01-20.</ref><ref name="60 creative years">Karen Price, [http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/news/2008/11/21/art-group-marking-60-creative-years-91466-22306900/ "Art group marking 60 creative years"], WalesOnline, 21 November 2008. Retrieved 2013-04-23.</ref><ref name="Planet Mapping">David Moore, [http://www.planetmagazine.org.uk/html/newsite/onlinedetails/The_Welsh_Group.html Mapping the Welsh Group at Sixty: The Exhibition], Planet Online. Retrieved 2013-04-23.</ref><ref>http://www.llgc.org.uk/index.php?id=1513&no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1386&cHash=8e57b2d7d9bdf30aa36c37d7d06e3731</ref><ref>http://welshgroup.co.uk/WGrpIndex.htm</ref> The group’s initial conception was in response to the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art|Royal Cambrian Academy’s]] relatively weak representation from [[south Wales]] at the time. In 1956 when the ''South Wales Group'' failed to become a southern Academy, the [[56 Group Wales]] also emerged,<ref name="50 years">Peter Wakelin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aXYySHER7x8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=50+Years+of+the+Welsh+Group.+Peter+Wakelin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IF8vUcqiBoe50QWNxYDQCA&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA “50 years of the Welsh Group"], National Museum of Wales (1999), {{ISBN|0-7200-0472-1}}</ref> with the aim of promoting modern Welsh art beyond Wales' borders.<ref>Peter Wakelin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aXYySHER7x8C&pg=PA43&dq=Arthur+Giardelli&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xFpTT5i_EKOA0AXpzLDpCw&ved=0CF8QuwUwCA#v=onepage&q=Arthur%20Giardelli&f=false "50 years of the Welsh Group"], National Museum of Wales (1999), pp. 39–43, {{ISBN|0-7200-0472-1}}</ref> Also in the industrial valleys the [[Dowlais]] Settlement, delivering art classes and activities was established in the 1940s by artists including [[Heinz Koppel]] and [[Arthur Giardelli]] and the [[Rhondda Group]] was formed in the 1950s, a loose group of art students whose most notable member was [[Ernest Zobole]], whose expressionist work was deeply rooted in the juxtaposition of the industrialised buildings of the valleys set against the green hills that surround them.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/ernest-zobole/ | title=Walesart, Ernest Zobole | work=BBC Wales online | author= | date= | accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> In the 1970s, Paul Davies formed [[Beca (artist group)|Beca]], a radical Welsh group whose founding was in part a reaction to the drowning of [[Capel Celyn]].<ref name="ArtinWales">{{cite web | url=http://www.artcornwall.org/features/Iwan_Bala_Art_in_Wales.htm | title=Art in Wales: Politics of Engagement or Engagement with Politics? | work=artcornwall.org | author= | date= | accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> Beca used a mixture of artistic expression, including installation, painting, sculpture and performance, engaging with language, environmental and land rights issues.<ref>Davies (2008) p. 56</ref>
==Decorative arts== [[File:Dynevor Service (Plate) LACMA 55.101.4b.jpg|thumb|Swansea porcelain plate, c. 1817]] South Wales had several notable potteries in the late 18th and 19th centuries, beginning with the [[Cambrian Pottery]] (1764–1870, also known as "[[Swansea]] pottery") and including [[Nantgarw Pottery]] near Cardiff, which was in operation from 1813 to 1822 making fine [[porcelain]], and then utilitarian pottery until 1920. [[Portmeirion Pottery]] (from 1961) has never in fact been made in Wales.
Despite the fact that considerable quantities of [[silver]] (in association with [[lead]]), and much smaller amounts of [[gold]], were mined in Wales, there was little silversmithing in Wales in the Early Modern period. It did not help that the Crown gave itself ownership of mines of [[precious metal]]s, which were largely used for minting currency, some of which was marked with the [[Prince of Wales's feathers]] to show its origin. The Welsh gentry mostly had their silver made in English cities.
==Contemporary Welsh Art== Today Welsh and Wales based artists, including members of [[The Welsh Group]], the [[56 Group Wales]], the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art|Royal Cambrian Academy]] and artists not affiliated with any particular group, provide a varied [[contemporary art|contemporary]] tapestry of art across Wales. From the [[Abstract Art]] of Brendan Stuart Burns<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.wales/arts-in-wales/inspire/make/creative-wales/creative-wales-archive/awards-2013-14/brendan-stuart-burns |title=Brendan Stuart Burns |work=Arts Council in Wales |accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref> or [[Martyn Jones (painter)|Martyn Jones]], to the expressive, modern figurative art of [[Shani Rhys James]], [[Clive Hicks-Jenkins]] or Rhŷn Williams, from the politically charged work of [[Iwan Bala]] or [[Ivor Davies (artist)|Ivor Davies]] to the [[Pop Art]] of [[Ken Elias]]. The contemporary art of Wales is noted perhaps more for its variety, rather than having a single set agenda. However, perhaps due to market forces or the inspirational shapes and changing light, the Welsh landscape is still particularly well represented in commercial galleries throughout Wales and beyond, either through the expressive, almost abstract, techniques used by artists like [[David Tress]] or the more traditional approaches used by others like [[Rob Piercy]].
==Conceptual art in Wales== [[File:B for Defiance by David Garner.jpg|thumb|left|150px|B for Defiance by David Garner]] Conceptual art is represented in Wales with a number of successful artists including [[Bedwyr Williams]] and [[David Garner (artist)|David Garner]] together with performance artists like the group TRACE,<ref>http://huwdavidjones.wordpress.com/2008/08/01/trace-displaced-gwaithwork/</ref><ref>http://www.performance-wales.org/events/tracedisplaced.html</ref> creating and showing work in Wales and beyond. A number of Welsh galleries focus on conceptual art, with the most significant perhaps being ''Mostyn''<ref>http://www.mostyn.org/</ref> in north Wales and ''[[Chapter Arts Centre]]'' and ''g|39''<ref>http://www.g39.org/</ref> in south Wales. The Gold Medal at '[[Y Lle Celf]]' in the [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]] has seen a notable trend towards more conceptual approaches over the last ten or so years, with [[Installation art|Installation work]] being the usual focal point.<ref>http://huwdavidjones.wordpress.com/2008/08/01/art-at-the-national-eisteddfod-of-wales/</ref> The 2003 development of the Artes Mundi prize and Wales's presence at the Venice Biennale has strengthened the country's international reputation for [[Conceptual art|Conceptual]] and [[Installation art]].
===Artes Mundi and Wales at the Venice Biennale===
Since 2003 the [[Artes Mundi]] biennial art prize has been held at the [[National Museum Cardiff]]. The prize is the biggest art prize in the [[United Kingdom]] with £40,000 for each year’s winner.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/posts/artes-mundi-5-at-national-museum-cardiff</ref> Though the prize has included artists who use traditional media, like paint, this is usually only part of their practice, with the focus being very much on conceptual approaches. Though the exhibition takes place in Cardiff, the focus is on international artists,<ref>http://www.artesmundi.org/</ref><ref>http://www.walesartsreview.org/artes-mundi-5-national-museum-cardiff/</ref><ref>http://www.walesonline.co.uk/all-about/artes%20mundi</ref> with Tim Davies from Pembrokeshire <ref>http://www.artesmundi.org/en/exhibitions-prizes/artes-mundi-one</ref> and [[Cornwall]] born Sue Williams<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/sue-williams/</ref> being the only Wales based artists to have featured to date.
Also adding to the international flavour in 2003, Wales took part in the [[Venice Biennale]] with its own pavilion<ref>http://www.artscouncilofwales.org.uk/artsinwales/venice</ref><ref>http://venicebiennale.britishcouncil.org/uk-in-venice</ref> and has continued to do so ever since, showing work by conceptual Welsh artists including [[John Cale]] in 2009,<ref>http://venicebiennale.britishcouncil.org/people/reference/john-cale</ref> Tim Davies in 2011<ref>http://www.wai.org.uk/news/2235</ref> and [[Bedwyr Williams]] in 2013.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-22736582</ref>
{{clear}}

International Observances denote a period to observe an issue of international interest or concern. Many of these observances have been established by either the [[United Nations General Assembly]], [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] or by the [[World Health Organization]]. World Health Observances mark a period which is often used to promote an issue and mobilize for action. Below follows a list of days and months which have been denoted as health related observances.<ref>http://nhslocal.nhs.uk/my-health/equip/events/list</ref><ref>https://www.un.org/en/events/observances/days.shtml</ref>
==January== * 4 January - World Braille Day * 30 January - [[World Leprosy Day]]
==February== *[[World Cancer Day]] *[[World Day of the Sick]] *International Childhood Cancer Day{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} *[[Rare Disease Day]]
==March== *[[World Tuberculosis Day]]
==April== *[[World Health Day]] *World Parkinson’s Awareness Day{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} *European Patients Rights Day{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} *[[World Malaria Day]] *[http://www.testicularcancerawarenessmonth.com Testicular Cancer Awareness Month]
==May== *European Cancer Prevention Week{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
==June== * [[Children's Day|International Day for Protection of Children]]{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} * [[World Blood Donor Day]] * [http://www.menshealthmonth.org Men’s Health Month] * [[National Safety Council|National Safety Month]] * [http://www.InternationalMensHealthWeek.com International Men’s Health Week] * [http://www.MensHealthWeek.com Men’s Health Week]
==July== * [[World Hepatitis Day]]

==October== *[[Breast Cancer Awareness Month]] *[[World Mental Health Day]] *World Arthritis Day{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} *[[World Osteoporosis Day]]
==November== *[[World Diabetes Day]]
